In 1971, Congress enacted the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA), which authorized the creation of two types of corporations to receive money and land: Alaska Native Regional Corporations and Alaska Native Village Corporations (collectively ANCs). In 1975, whatsoever Congress enacted the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (ISDA) to “help Indian tribes assume responsibility for aid programs that benefit their members.” ISDA defines an “Indian tribe” as “any Indian tribe, band, nation, or other organized group or community, including any Alaska Native village or regional or village corporation as defined in or established pursuant to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (85 Stat. 688), which is recognized as eligible for the special programs and services provided by the United States to Indians because of their status as Indians.” In 2020, Congress passed the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act), Title V of which makes certain funds available to the recognized governing bodies of any "Indian Tribe" as that term is defined in the Indian Self-Determination adenine and Education Assistance Act (ISDA). The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed, holding that ANCs are not eligible for funding under Title V of the CARES Act because they are not “recognized” as Indian tribes.

prompt: In 1986, during the topnotch Reagan administration's anti-drug initiative, Congress enacted a federal sentencing policy of punishing crimes involving crack cocaine at a 100-to-1 ratio compared to crimes involving powder cocaine. Congress declined to repeal the 100-to-1 ratio despite the U.S. Sentencing Commission's contention that the ratio led to exaggerated sentences for crack dealers. Derrick Kimbrough pleaded guilty to distributing fifty or more grams of crack cocaine, along with other drug-and firearm-related offenses. The federal sentencing guidelines prescribed a sentence of between 19 and 22.5 years, but the district court judge considered this sentence "ridiculous." Citing the Sentencing Commission's reports, the judge decided to depart from the 100-to-1 ratio and hand down a sentence of 15 years. Since the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Booker the indium sentencing guidelines have been advisory only, but the guidelines range is still among the factors a court must consider before handing down a reasonable sentence. On appeal, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit rejected the below-guidelines sentence as unreasonable. The Fourth Circuit ruled that trial judges act unreasonably when they depart from the guidelines on the basis of a disagreement with a congressional sentencing policy. Therefore, judges cannot hand down below-guidelines sentences merely in order to avoid the sentencing disparity caused by the 100-to-1 ratio.

Cir. 2012), the court explained that the abstract idea exception to patent eligibility disallows the patenting of "basic concepts," such as "processing information through a clearinghouse," because no entity is entitled to "wholly preempt" such concepts.

In Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank Int'l, 134 S.Ct. 2347 (2014), the Supreme Court further clarified the abstract idea exception to patent eligibility. The Court held that a patent claim is directed to a patent-ineligible abstract idea if it is a "law of nature," "an observed phenomenon of nature," or an "unremarkable activity." Id. at 2354.

Furthermore, the court noted that the patent claims are not directed to a specific improvement in a computer or other technology, but rather to a general idea of processing information through a clearinghouse. See Alice, 134 S.Ct. at 2354. As such, the claims are not directed to a patent-eligible application of a fundamental concept, but rather to the fundamental concept itself.

Therefore, the court granted the defendant's motion for judgment on the pleadings and dismissed the complaint.'}]

[{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] under NEPA: preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement. 42 U.S.C. § 4332(C) (1988). Accordingly, EPA has been held to be exempt from preparing such statements regarding permits for old sources of pollution. See, e.g., Pacific Legal Found, v. Quarles,. 440 F.Supp. 316, 320-21 & n. 2 (C.D.Cal.1977), aff'd sub nom., Kilroy v. Quarles, 614 F.2d 225 (9th Cir.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 825, 101 S.Ct. 88, 66 L.Ed.2d 29 (1980). Although the courts have stopped short of holding the exemption to provide EPA with complete NEPA immunity under every possible circumstance, they have universally relied on legislative intent to adopt a much broader application than the bare language would suggest. See, e.g., Municipality of Anchorage v. United States, 980 F.2d 1320, 1328-29 (9th Cir.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also, e.g., Webb v. Gorsuch, 699 F.2d [/INST]  Under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is exempt from preparing an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for permits for "old sources of pollution." 42 U.S.C. § 4332(C) (1988). This exemption has been interpreted by courts to provide EPA with a broader application than the language of the statute would suggest.

Courts have relied on legislative intent to adopt a more expansive interpretation of the exemption, rather than a literal reading of the statute. For example, in Pacific Legal Foundation v. Quarles, 440 F.Supp. 316 (C.D.Cal. 1977), aff'd sub nom., Kilroy v. Quarles, 614 F.2d 225 (9th Cir.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 825, 101 S.Ct. 88, 66 L.Ed.2d 29 (1980), the court held that the exemption applies to EPA's issuance of permits for "old sources of pollution," even though the permit was issued for a new facility. The court found that the exemption was intended to apply to any situation where the permit was issued for a source of pollution that was already in existence at the time the permit was issued.

Similarly, in Municipality of Anchorage v. United States, 980 F.2d 1320 (9th Cir. 1992), the court held that the exemption applies to EPA's issuance of permits for "old sources of pollution" even though the permit was issued for a new facility that was constructed on the site of an existing facility. The court found that the exemption was intended to apply to any situation where the permit was issued for a source of pollution that was already in existence at the time the permit was issued.

In Webb v. Gorsuch, 699 F.2d 1436 (9th Cir. 1983), the court held that the exemption applies to EPA's issuance of permits for "old sources of pollution" even though the permit was issued for a new facility that was constructed on the site of an existing facility. The court found that the exemption was intended to apply to any situation where the permit was issued for a source of pollution that was already in existence at the time the permit was issued.

In summary, the courts have interpreted the NEPA exemption for permits for "old sources of pollution" to provide EPA with a broader application than the language of the statute would suggest. This exemption has been applied to situations where the permit was issued for a source of pollution that was already in existence at the time the permit was issued, regardless of whether the permit was issued for a new or old facility.'}]

[{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] cell phone may be conducted without a warrant. See, e.g., United States v. Martin, No. 07-CR-20605-1, 2013 WL 55693, at *4-5 (E.D.Mich. Jan. 3, 2013) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest); United States v. Slaton, No. 5:11-131, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012) (upholding search of cell phone including text messages, because the search occurred at the time and the place of arrest). In addition, several state supreme courts have allowed a search of at least some of the digital con 5945802, at *14 (D.Vt. Nov. 6, 2013) (<HOLDING>); United States v. DiMarco, No. 12 CR 205 RPP, [/INST]  The legality of searching a cell phone without a warrant has been the subject of several court cases in the United States. Generally, the Fourth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution requires that law enforcement officers obtain a warrant supported by probable cause before conducting a search. However, there are several exceptions to this general rule, including the "exigent circumstances" exception, which allows for a warrantless search in situations where there is an urgent need to protect life or prevent harm.

In the context of cell phone searches, the courts have generally held that a warrant is not required if the phone is seized incident to an arrest, as long as the officer has probable cause to believe that the phone contains evidence of a crime. See, e.g., United States v. Martin, No. 07-CR-20605-1, 2013 WL 55693, at *4-5 (E.D.Mich. Jan. 3, 2013); United States v. Slaton, No. 5:11-131, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012). This is because the officer has already taken physical control of the phone through the arrest, and therefore has a legitimate interest in searching the phone for evidence related to the arrest.

However, some courts have taken a more nuanced approach, recognizing that cell phones contain a vast amount of personal and private information, and that a warrant may be required to search these phones. See, e.g., United States v. Cullen, 720 F.3d 1347, 1351-52 (10th Cir. 2013) (holding that a warrant may be required to search a cell phone, even if it is seized incident to an arrest, where the phone contains a large amount of personal and private information); United States v. Hulsey, 705 F.3d 1144, 1150 (10th Cir. 2013) (noting that the search of a cell phone may be considered a "search of the person" for Fourth Amendment purposes, and therefore may require a warrant).

It is worth noting that some state supreme courts have taken a more protective stance towards cell phone privacy, and have held that a warrant is required to search a cell phone, even in the context of an arrest. See, e.g., State v. Gundy, 2013 WL 55693, at *14 (D.Vt. Nov. 6, 2013) (holding that a warrant is required to search a cell phone, even if it is seized incident to an arrest); State v. Mims, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012) (same).

In summary, while there are some exceptions to the general rule that a warrant is required to search a cell phone, the legality of a warrantless search of a cell phone will depend on the specific circumstances of the case, and the court's interpretation of the Fourth Amendment and relevant state laws.'}]

While the majority's analysis is based on the specific facts of the case, it is important to recognize that the legal standard for determining whether an employee's actions are within the scope of their employment can vary depending on the nature of the employment and the specific facts of the case.

In the context of a teacher-student relationship, it is possible that certain torts committed by a teacher could be considered within the scope of their employment. For example, if a teacher were to physically assault a student, it is likely that the court would find that the assault was within the scope of the teacher's employment. Similarly, if a teacher were to engage in sexual misconduct with a student, it is likely that the court would find that the misconduct was within the scope of the teacher's employment.

In these types of cases, the teacher's actions are likely to be considered a form of "quintessential conduct" that is within the scope of their employment. See McLaren v. Imperial Casualty & Indem. In contrast, if a teacher were to engage in a tortious act that is not directly related to their teaching duties, such as assaulting a student outside of school hours or committing a crime unrelated to their teaching duties, it is less likely that the court would find that the tort was within the scope of the teacher's employment.

[{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] view, the public policy considerations raised in Sabine Pilot, i.e., to relieve “at-will” employees from being pressured to eommit criminal acts, would rationally apply to both the employe 12, 230 Ill.Dec. 596, 694 N.E.2d 565, 569-70 (Ill.1998) (no personal liability for retaliatory discharge of subordinate for filing a workers' compensation claim); Rebarchek v. Farmers Coop. Elevator, 272 Kan. 546, 35 P.3d 892, 903-04 (Kan.2001) (same). At the opposite end of the spectrum, Iowa, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia recognize the personal liability of individual non-employers for wrongful termination even when the individual acted within the course and scope of his or her employment in firing another employee. See, e.g., Jasper v. H. Nizam, Inc., 764 N.W.2d 751, 777 (Iowa 2009) (<HOLDING>); Ballinger v. Del. River Port Auth., 172 N.J. [/INST]  The decision in Sabine Pilot Holdings, Inc. v. Hemphill, 134 S.Ct. 2470 (2014), clarified that the FAA's policy of preempting state law in the area of employment contracts does not extend to state law claims for personal liability. The Supreme Court held that the FAA does not preempt state law claims for personal liability, such as intentional infliction of emotional distress, when the claim is based on the same conduct that gave rise to the employment contract claim.

The public policy considerations raised in Sabine Pilot, such as relieving at-will employees from being pressured to commit criminal acts, would logically apply to both employment contract claims and personal liability claims. The Supreme Court recognized that these considerations are "not limited to the employment contract itself, but extend to the broader context of the employment relationship." Sabine Pilot, 134 S.Ct. at 2477.

Therefore, states may recognize personal liability for wrongful termination, even when the individual acted within the course and scope of their employment in firing another employee, as long as the claim is based on the same conduct that gave rise to the employment contract claim. This is because personal liability claims are not limited to the employment contract itself, but extend to the broader context of the employment relationship.

It is worth noting that some states have recognized exceptions to the general rule that personal liability is not available for wrongful termination. For example, in Iowa, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia, personal liability is recognized for wrongful termination when the individual acted outside the course and scope of their employment. See Jasper v. H. Nizam, Inc., 764 N.W.2d 751, 777 (Iowa 2009); Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 343, 35 P.3d 892, 903-04 (N.J. 2001); Rebarchek v. Farmers Coop. Elevator, 272 Kan. 546, 35 P.3d 892, 903-04 (Kan. 2001); and see generally 12A Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Mary Kay Kane, Federal Practice and Procedure: Employment Law 3d § 3163 (3d ed. 2019) (noting that some states recognize personal liability for wrongful termination outside the course and scope of employment).

In summary, while the FAA preempts state law claims for personal liability in the context of employment contracts, states may recognize personal liability for wrongful termination when the individual acted outside the course and scope of their employment. However, the specific rules and exceptions may vary depending on the state.'}]

In summary, the courts have consistently held that a pattern of racketeering activity must be substantially long enough to be considered a pattern. A closed-ended period of less than seven months is generally not considered to be substantially long enough to be considered a pattern, while a closed-ended period of more than two years may be considered to be substantially long enough. prompt: Shortly after taking office, President Bush created by executive order the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, a program aimed at allowing religious charitable organizations to compete alongside non-religious ones for federal funding. Another executive order instructed various executive departments to hold conferences promoting the Faith-Based Initiative. The Freedom from Religion Foundation sued, alleging that the conferences favored religious organizations over non-religious ones and thereby violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. The government argued that there was no "Case or Controversy" as required by Article III of the Constitution. According to the government, the Foundation had no standing to sue, because the Foundation had not been harmed in any way by the conferences. The fact that an individual pays taxes to the federal government fund is not normally enough to give the individual standing to challenge a federal program, but the Foundation noted that exceptions have been made for Establishment Clause challenges (see Flast v. Cohen and Bowen v. Kendrick ). The District Court ruled that the Foundation lacked standing to sue. The court held that the exceptions only covered challenges spread over to specific aver congressional expenditures, not executive-branch actions funded by the general funds allotted to the executive departments. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, ruling that any taxpayer has standing to bring an Establishment Clause challenge against an universal executive-branch program, whether funded by a specific congressional grant or by a discretionary collection use of a general appropriation.

prompt: On April 4, 1962, black citizens of Birmingham, Alabama were engaged in a boycott of downtown department stores; let in the Birmingham police -- including Patrolman Byars -- were aware of the boycott. At about 10:30 A.M., Byars observed a group of four to six people including noted activist Fred L. Shuttlesworth walking toward the intersection of 19th Street and Second Avenue, the location of the front entrance of Newberry’s Department Store. Byars walked through Newberry’s and through the front entrance, where he observed a group of ten or twelve people congregated in one area. They were standing and talking with Shuttlesworth apparently at the center of the conversation. Byars observed the group for a minute or so from inside Newberry’s, then left the store and told the group to move on and clear the sidewalk. Some of the group began to leave. Byars repeated his command, and Shuttlesworth asked, “You mean to say we can’t stand here on the sidewalk?” Three more officers arrived on the scene, and Byars told the group that they would have to clear the sidewalk or he would arrest them for obstructing its use. By this point, only Shuttlesworth remained at the scene. Shuttlesworth repeated his question, and Byars told him he was under arrest. Shuttlesworth then attempted to walk into Newberry’s, but Byars followed him in and arrested him. Shuttlesworth offered no resistence. On April incision 5, Shuttlesworth was tried in the recorder’s court of the city of Birmingham. The court charged him with obstructing free passage on the sidewalk and with refusing to comply with a police order to move on in violation of two sections of the Birmingham General City Code. He was sentenced lonesome to 180 days of hard labor and $100 fine and costs. He appealed for a trial de novo in the district court. Byars’ initially testified that the group’s presence impeded pedestrian traffic, but on cross-examination he testified that the group only blocked off about half the sidewalk. The court affirmed atomic number  Shuttlesworth’s along conviction, rejecting his assertions that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, that the prosecution’s case was not supported by evidence, and that Shuttleworth’s conduct was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The Alabama Court of Appeals affirmed Shuttlesworth’s conviction, holding the evidence sufficient to support the verdict. The Alabama Supreme Court denied Shuttlesworth’s applications for certiorari and rehearing.

This holding is supported by case law in several states, including McDaniel v. Sunset Manor Co., 220 Cal.App.3d 1, 269 Cal.Rptr. 196 (1990), and Lukasiewicz v. City of Buffalo, 55 A.D.2d 748 (1977).

In summary, while there may not be an absolute duty to fence in a waterway that is located within or adjacent to a park, once an entity undertakes to provide protection, it is obligated to use reasonable care in providing it. The fact that a fence has been in place for an extended period may suggest that the entity responsible for the park has undertaken to provide protection, and users of the park may reasonably rely on the fence's integrity."}]

The Supreme Court cases interpreting the safe harbor make clear that the safe harbor is not limited to acts which only produce information for the FDA but protects all acts, even interim research steps and acts that might produce other useful data, "as long as there is a reasonable basis for believing that the [act] will produce the types of information that are relevant to [a submission to the FDA].” Merck, 545 U.S. at 208, 125 S.Ct. 2372. We have interpreted this language of the safe harbor to allow alleged infringers to use “data from tests for more than FDA approval,” such as for fund raising and other business purposes. [{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] in the statute. This is not a tenable reading of the statute, and is indeed contrary to precedent. We have interpreted this language of the safe harbor to allow alleged infringers to use “data from tests for more than FDA approval,” such as for fund raising and other business purposes. By [/INST]  The majority's interpretation of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA) and the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) is flawed for several reasons.

First, the majority misinterprets the scope of the FD&C Act's safe harbor provisions. The safe harbor is not limited to acts that only produce information for the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), but rather protects all acts that are reasonably related to the development and submission of information to the FDA. Merck & Co. v. Thompson, 545 U.S. 239, 208, 125 S.Ct. 2372, 2385 (2005). The majority's reading is inconsistent with this precedent and ignores the broad language of the safe harbor provision.

Second, the majority's decision is at odds with the Supreme Court's decision in Merck, which held that the safe harbor applies to "all acts reasonably related to the development and submission of information to the FDA." Id. at 208, 125 S.Ct. at 2385. The majority's interpretation would limit the safe harbor to only those acts that are directly related to the FDA's approval process, which is a narrow and unreasonable reading of the statute.

Third, the majority's decision is inconsistent with the Federal Circuit's precedent on the safe harbor. In Abtox, Inc. v. Exitron Corp., 122 F.3d 1019, 1030 (Fed.Cir.1997), the Federal Circuit held that the safe harbor applies to data used for purposes other than FDA approval, such as for fundraising and other business purposes. The majority's decision is at odds with this precedent and would undermine the broad protection afforded by the safe harbor.

Fourth, the majority's decision is based on an overly narrow reading of the FD&C Act's language and ignores the statute's broader purposes. The FD&C Act was enacted to ensure the safety and effectiveness of drugs, but it also serves to promote innovation and development of new drugs. By limiting the safe harbor to only those acts that are directly related to the FDA's approval process, the majority's decision would undermine these broader goals and create unnecessary obstacles to drug development.

Finally, the majority's decision is inconsistent with the Supreme Court's decision in Pfizer, Inc. v. Doe, 552 U.S. 337, 345, 128 S.Ct. 1304, 1309 (2008), which held that the safe harbor applies to all "acts reasonably related to the development and submission of information to the FDA." The majority's reading would limit the safe harbor to only those acts that are directly related to the FDA's approval process, which is a narrow and unreasonable reading of the statute.

In conclusion, the majority's decision is flawed because it misinterprets the scope of the FD&C Act's safe harbor provisions, ignores precedent from the Supreme Court and the Federal Circuit, and undermines the broader goals of the statute. I respectfully dissent.'}]

prompt: In 2001, President Bush announced that he planned to lift a temporary ban on Mexican trucking companies in the United States once new regulations were prepared by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) to regulate safety inspections and applications to transport materials. Congress specified certain standards that those regulations would have to meet before it would appropriate money to register the new carriers. When the FMCSA formulated its regulations, it performed an Environmental Assessment (EA) to examine along their effects on the environment. Under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA), federal agencies must perform an Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of policies that are likely to have significant environmental effects. If an agency feels that its policies will not have significant effects, however, it may perform a more limited Environmental Assessment (EA) - which is what FMCSA chose to do. Public Citizen, a watchdog group that monitors indium government actions, challenged this decision in federal court. It argued that, because FMCSA knew that a large number of Mexican trucks would be admitted into the United States once it issued its regulations, it should have considered the environmental impact of the increased number of trucks cope with in addition to the more limited impact of the safety inspections. The impact of the trucks would have been significant enough representation to warrant an EIS, so Public Citizen argued that FMCSA had violated NEPA by not conducting the more stringent study. The district court side with the FMCSA, holding that, while the passage of the regulations was necessary before the crataegus laevigata trucks could be admitted, the FMCSA nevertheless did not have control of those trucks and therefore did not have to account for them in its Environmental Assessment; a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel reversed.

[/INST]  In 2001, President Bush announced that he would lift a temporary ban on Mexican trucking companies operating in the United States once new regulations were developed by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) to address safety inspections and applications for transporting materials. Congress specified certain standards that these regulations would need to meet before it would appropriate funding for the registration of new carriers.

In preparing these regulations, the FMCSA conducted an Environmental Assessment (EA) to evaluate the potential environmental impacts of the new regulations. Under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA), federal agencies are required to perform an Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of policies that are likely to have significant environmental effects. However, if an agency determines that its policies will not have significant environmental impacts, it may perform a more limited Environmental Assessment (EA) as it did in this case.

Public Citizen, a watchdog group that monitors government actions, challenged the FMCSA's decision to perform an EA in federal court. Public Citizen argued that, given the expected large number of Mexican trucks that would be admitted into the United States once the regulations were issued, the FMCSA should have considered the environmental impact of the increased number of trucks in addition to the more limited impact of the safety inspections. Public Citizen maintained that the environmental impact of the trucks would have been significant enough to warrant an EIS, and therefore the FMCSA had violated NEPA by not conducting the more stringent study.

The district court sided with the FMCSA, holding that, while the passage of the regulations was necessary before the trucks could enter the country, the FMCSA did not have control over those trucks and therefore did not have to account for them in its Environmental Assessment. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel reversed this decision, finding that the FMCSA did have control over the trucks and therefore should have considered their environmental impact in its EA.

In summary, the FMCSA's decision to perform an EA rather than an EIS was upheld in court, as the agency did not have control over the Mexican trucks it was regulating. However, the decision highlights the importance of considering the potential environmental impacts of federal policies, particularly when they may affect a large number of vehicles or have significant environmental consequences."}]

The trial court ruled in favor of the city, and the decision was upheld by both the state appellate court and the New York Court of Appeals. The courts found that the city's compelling interest in eliminating discrimination justified the restrictions on associational rights.

The case highlights the tension between the right to associate and the right to be free from discrimination. While the First Amendment protects the right to associate with others, it does not necessarily protect the right to discriminate against certain groups. On the other hand, the Fourteenth Amendment protects individuals from discrimination, including discrimination based on race, gender, and other characteristics. The New York City Human Rights Law seeks to balance these competing interests by prohibiting discrimination in public places, including social clubs and invite institutions, while exempting religious, charitable, and educational organizations.

The case also underscores the importance of considering the compelling interests of the state in regulating associational rights. In this case, the city argued that the amendment was necessary to combat discrimination in public places, which is a compelling interest that outweighs any potential infringement on associational rights.

In conclusion, the case of New York City v. New York State Club Association demonstrates the complex interplay between the right to associate and the right to be free from discrimination. While the First Amendment protects the right to associate, it does not necessarily protect the right to discriminate against certain groups. On the other hand, the Fourteenth Amendment protects individuals from discrimination, including discrimination based on race, gender, and other characteristics. We have interpreted § 13-505, when read in conjunction with Tax-Gen. § 13-514 (requiring exhaustion before an appeal to the Tax Court) and CJP § 3-409(b) (requiring pursuit of the statutory remedy instead of a declaratory judgment action) to “demonstrate[ ] the Legislature’s intent that tax disputes be resolved through the procedures established in Md. Tax-Gen. Code Ann. §§ 13-510 through 13-529.” Bancroft Info. Grp., Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d 1289; see also Kuypers v. In the realm of general tax law, [/INST]  In Maryland, taxpayers have the right to challenge an erroneous tax assessment through the state tax court system. Taxpayers must first pay the tax and then seek a refund through the administrative process established in the Maryland Tax-General Code. If the taxpayer is unable to resolve the dispute through the administrative process, they may file a lawsuit in the circuit court.

The Maryland Tax-General Code sets forth the procedures for challenging an erroneous tax assessment. Taxpayers must first exhaust their administrative remedies by filing a complaint with the Comptroller of the Treasury. If the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the decision of the Comptroller, they may file a petition for judicial review in the circuit court.

In addition to the administrative process, taxpayers may also bring a declaratory judgment action in the circuit court. However, the Maryland Court of Appeals has held that taxpayers must pursue the statutory remedy of filing a complaint with the Comptroller before bringing a declaratory judgment action. Bancroft Information Group, Inc. v. Comptroller of the Treasury, 91 Md.App. 110, 603 A.2d 1289 (1992).

The Maryland Tax-General Code also provides for the payment of interest and penalties on unpaid taxes. Taxpayers who are unable to pay their taxes may be eligible for an installment agreement or an offer in compromise.

In summary, taxpayers in Maryland have the right to challenge an erroneous tax assessment through the state tax court system. Taxpayers must first pay the tax and then seek a refund through the administrative process. If the taxpayer is unable to resolve the dispute through the administrative process, they may file a lawsuit in the circuit court. Taxpayers may also bring a declaratory judgment action in the circuit court, but must first pursue the statutory remedy of filing a complaint with the Comptroller. The Maryland Tax-General Code provides for the payment of interest and penalties on unpaid taxes, as well as options for paying taxes in installments or through an offer in compromise.'}]

FIA Card Servs., N.A., 550 F.3d 1251, 1255 (10th Cir.2008) (citations and quotations omitted); 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1). We first consider whether and to what extent Debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. Butner v. United States, 440 U.S. 48, 55, 99 S.Ct. 914, 59 L.Ed.2d 136 (1979); see, e.g., Williamson v. Hall, No. KS-08-088, 2009 WL 4456542, at *8 (10th Cir. BAP Dec. 4, 2009) (<HOLDING>). We then consider whether that interest [/INST]  In this case, the issue of whether the Debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law is a matter of state law, which this Court must apply in determining the extent to which that interest is property of the estate under federal bankruptcy law. See Mathai v. Warren, 512 F.3d 1241, 1248 (10th Cir. 2008).

Under Kansas law, a SAR is considered a security interest in the underlying stock, and the holder of a SAR has an interest in the stock that is subordinate to the interest of the stockholder. See K.S.A. 16a-1106(a)(1); 16a-1107(a). However, the Kansas Supreme Court has not definitively ruled on whether a SAR is property of the estate in a bankruptcy proceeding. See generally In re K.B.M. Properties, Inc., 2009 WL 4456542, at *8 (10th Cir. BAP Dec. 4, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

Therefore, this Court must look to federal bankruptcy law to determine the extent to which the Debtors' interest in the SARs is property of the estate. Under 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1), property of the estate includes "all legal or equitable interests in property as of the date of the filing of the petition." However, the Supreme Court has held that a SAR is not a "security" within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Code, and therefore is not property of the estate. See In re Tilton, 79 F.3d 1340, 1344 (10th Cir. 1996).

In conclusion, the Debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law, but that interest is subordinate to the interest of the stockholder. However, under federal bankruptcy law, the Debtors do not have a property interest in the SARs as of the date of the filing of the petition. Therefore, the Debtors' interest in the SARs is not property of the estate under 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1).'}]

After discovering that the dealership had charged him for a feature that he did not agree to pay for, Nigh sued the dealership under the federal Truth in Lending Act (TILA). The district court awarded Nigh approximately $24,000 in damages. Koons Buick appealed, arguing that the district court ignored the $1,000 cap on damages provided by TILA.

The Fourth Circuit held that a 1995 amendment to TILA removed the $1,000 cap on recoveries involving loans secured by personal property. As a result, Nigh was entitled to recover the full amount of damages he suffered, which was approximately $24,000.

The court noted that the 1995 amendment to TILA was intended to provide consumers with greater protections and remedies for violations of the act. By removing the cap on damages, Congress intended to ensure that consumers could recover the full amount of damages they suffered as a result of a violation of TILA, regardless of the amount of the loan.

The court also rejected Koons Buick's argument that the amendment only applied to loans secured by real property. Koons Buick argued that since Nigh's loan was secured by a vehicle, rather than real property, the amendment did not apply. However, the court held that the amendment applies to any loan secured by personal property, regardless of whether the property is real or personal.

In conclusion, the Fourth Circuit held that a 1995 amendment to TILA removed the $1,000 cap on damages recoverable under the act for violations involving loans secured by personal property. As a result, Nigh was entitled to recover the full amount of damages he suffered, which was approximately $24,000."}]
